Classification of computer-assisted plagiarism detection methods













  
     Plagiarism detection  is the process of locating instances of  plagiarism within a work or document. The widespread use of computers and the advent of the Internet has made it easier to plagiarize the work of others. Most cases of plagiarism are found in academia, where documents are typically essays or reports. However, plagiarism can be found in virtually any field, including scientific papers, art designs, and source code. 
  Detection of plagiarism can be either manual or software-assisted. Manual detection requires substantial effort and excellent memory, and is impractical in cases where too many documents must be compared, or original documents are not available for comparison. Software-assisted detection allows vast collections of documents to be compared to each other, making successful detection much more likely. 
  The practice of plagiarizing by use of sufficient word substitutions to elude detection software is known as  rogeting.   [2]  
  
  
   Software-assisted detection    Computer-assisted plagiarism detection (CaPD) is an  Information retrieval (IR) task supported by specialized IR systems, referred to as plagiarism detection systems (PDS). 
   In text documents    Systems for text-plagiarism detection implement one of two generic detection approaches, one being external, the other being intrinsic.   [4]  External detection systems compare a suspicious document with a reference collection, which is a set of documents assumed to be genuine.   [6]  Based on a chosen  document model and predefined similarity criteria, the detection task is to retrieve all documents that contain text that is similar to a degree above a chosen threshold to text in the suspicious document.   [8]  Intrinsic PDS solely analyze the text to be evaluated without performing comparisons to external documents. This approach aims to recognize changes in the unique writing style of an author as an indicator for potential plagiarism.   [10]  PDS are not capable of reliably identifying plagiarism without human judgment. Similarities are computed with the help of predefined document models and might represent false positives.   [11]    [12]    [14]    [15]    [16]  
   Approaches    The figure below represents a classification of all detection approaches currently in use for computer-assisted plagiarism detection. The approaches are characterized by the type of similarity assessment they undertake: global or local. Global similarity assessment approaches use the characteristics taken from larger parts of the text or the document as a whole to compute similarity, while local methods only examine pre-selected text segments as input. 
  
   Fingerprinting    Fingerprinting is currently the most widely applied approach to plagiarism detection. This method forms representative digests of documents by selecting a set of multiple substrings (  n-grams) from them. The sets represent the fingerprints and their elements are called minutiae.   [19]    [20]  A suspicious document is checked for plagiarism by computing its fingerprint and querying minutiae with a precomputed index of fingerprints for all documents of a reference collection. Minutiae matching with those of other documents indicate shared text segments and suggest potential plagiarism if they exceed a chosen similarity threshold.   [22]  Computational resources and time are limiting factors to fingerprinting, which is why this method typically only compares a subset of minutiae to speed up the computation and allow for checks in very large collection, such as the Internet.   [19]  
   String matching     String matching is a prevalent approach used in computer science. When applied to the problem of plagiarism detection, documents are compared for verbatim text overlaps. Numerous methods have been proposed to tackle this task, of which some have been adapted to external plagiarism detection. Checking a suspicious document in this setting requires the computation and storage of efficiently comparable representations for all documents in the reference collection to compare them pairwise. Generally, suffix document models, such as  suffix trees or suffix vectors, have been used for this task. Nonetheless, substring matching remains computationally expensive, which makes it a non-viable solution for checking large collections of documents.   [24]    [25]    [27]  
   Bag of words    Bag of words analysis represent the adoption of  vector space retrieval, a traditional IR concept, to the domain of plagiarism detection. Documents are represented as one or multiple vectors, e.g. for different document parts, which are used for pair wise similarity computations. Similarity computation may then rely on the traditional  cosine similarity measure, or on more sophisticated similarity measures.   [29]    [30]    [31]  
   Citation analysis    Citation-based plagiarism detection (CbPD)   [32]  relies on citation analysis, and is the only approach to plagiarism detection that does not rely on the textual similarity.   [34]  CbPD examines the citation and reference information in texts to identify similar  patterns in the citation sequences. As such, this approach is suitable for scientific texts, or other academic documents that contain citations. Citation analysis to detect plagiarism is a relatively young concept. It has not been adopted by commercial software, but a first prototype of a citation-based plagiarism detection system exists.   [36]  Similar order and proximity of citations in the examined documents are the main criteria used to compute citation pattern similarities. Citation patterns represent subsequences non-exclusively containing citations shared by the documents compared.   [34]    [38]  Factors, including the absolute number or relative fraction of shared citations in the pattern, as well as the probability that citations co-occur in a document are also considered to quantify the patterns’ degree of similarity.   [34]    [38]    [40]    [42]  
   Stylometry     Stylometry subsumes statistical methods for quantifying an author’s unique writing style   [43]    [46]  and is mainly used for authorship attribution or intrinsic CaPD. By constructing and comparing stylometric models for different text segments, passages that are stylistically different from others, hence potentially plagiarized, can be detected.   [10]  
   Performance    Comparative evaluations of plagiarism detection systems   [6]    [47]    [48]    [49]    [50]    [51]  indicate that their performance depends on the type of plagiarism present (see figure). Except for citation pattern analysis, all detection approaches rely on textual similarity. It is therefore symptomatic that detection accuracy decreases the more plagiarism cases are obfuscated. 
  
  Literal copies, aka copy and paste (c&p) plagiarism, or modestly disguised plagiarism cases can be detected with high accuracy by current external PDS if the source is accessible to the software. Especially substring matching procedures achieve a good performance for c&p plagiarism, since they commonly use lossless document models, such as  suffix trees. The performance of systems using fingerprinting or bag of words analysis in detecting copies depends on the information loss incurred by the document model used. By applying flexible chunking and selection strategies, they are better capable of detecting moderate forms of disguised plagiarism when compared to substring matching procedures. 
  Intrinsic plagiarism detection using  stylometry can overcome the boundaries of textual similarity to some extent by comparing linguistic similarity. Given that the stylistic differences between plagiarized and original segments are significant and can be identified reliably, stylometry can help in identifying disguised and  paraphrased plagiarism. Stylometric comparisons are likely to fail in cases where segments are strongly paraphrased to the point where they more closely resemble the personal writing style of the plagiarist or if a text was compiled by multiple authors. The results of the International Competitions on Plagiarism Detection held in 2009, 2010 and 2011,   [6]    [50]    [51]  as well as experiments performed by Stein,   [54]  indicate that stylometric analysis seems to work reliably only for document lengths of several thousand or tens of thousands of words, which limits the applicability of the method to CaPD settings. 
  An increasing amount of research is performed on methods and systems capable of detecting translated plagiarisms. Currently, cross-language plagiarism detection (CLPD) is not viewed as a mature technology   [56]  and respective systems have not been able to achieve satisfying detection results in practice.   [49]  
  Citation-based plagiarism detection using citation pattern analysis is capable of identifying stronger paraphrases and translations with higher success rates when compared to other detection approaches, because it is independent of textual characteristics.   [34]    [40]  However, since citation-pattern analysis depends on the availability of sufficient citation information, it is limited to academic texts. It remains inferior to text-based approaches in detecting shorter plagiarized passages, which are typical for cases of copy-and-paste or shake-and-paste plagiarism; the latter refers to mixing slightly altered fragments from different sources.   [57]  
   Software    The design of plagiarism detection software for use with text documents is characterized by a number of factors: 
     Factor   Description and alternatives      Scope of search    In the public internet, using search engines / Institutional databases / Local, system-specific database.      Analysis time    Delay between the time a document is submitted and the time when results are made available.      Document capacity / Batch processing    Number of documents the system can process per unit of time.      Check intensity    How often and for which types of document fragments (paragraphs, sentences, fixed-length word sequences) does the system query external resources, such as search engines.      Comparison algorithm type    The algorithms that define the way the system uses to compare documents against each other.      Precision and Recall    Number of documents correctly flagged as plagiarized compared to the total number of flagged documents, and to the total number of documents that were actually plagiarized. High precision means that few  false positives were found, and high recall means that few  false negatives were left undetected.      Most large-scale plagiarism detection systems use large, internal databases (in addition to other resources) that grow with each additional document submitted for analysis. However, this feature is considered by some as a  violation of student copyright. 
  The following systems are mostly web-based, and are closed-source, with the exception of CitePlag and CopyTracker. The following list is non-exhaustive (see also  Comparison of anti-plagiarism software): 
          Free of charge     Chimpsky   [58]    [59]    CitePlag   [38]    CopyTracker   [58]    [59]    [60]     eTBLAST   Plagium   [59]    [61]    SeeSources   [59]    [62]          Commercial      Attributor    Copyscape    PlagTracker   Iparadigms:  Ithenticate,  Turnitin   PlagiarismDetect   [58]    [59]    PlagScan   [58]    [59]    VeriGuide   The Plagiarism Checker   [63]    [65]        
   In source code    Plagiarism in computer source code is also frequent, and requires different tools than those used for text comparisons in document. Significant research has been dedicated to academic source-code plagiarism.   [66]  
  A distinctive aspect of source-code plagiarism is that there are no  essay mills, such as can be found in traditional plagiarism. Since most programming assignments expect students to write programs with very specific requirements, it is very difficult to find existing programs that already meet them. Since integrating external code is often harder than writing it from scratch, most plagiarizing students choose to do so from their peers. 
  According to Roy and Cordy,   [67]  source-code similarity detection algorithms can be classified as based on either 
   Strings – look for exact textual matches of segments, for instance five-word runs. Fast, but can be confused by renaming identifiers. 
  Tokens – as with strings, but using a  lexer to convert the program into  tokens first. This discards whitespace, comments, and identifier names, making the system more robust to simple text replacements. Most academic plagiarism detection systems work at this level, using different algorithms to measure the similarity between token sequences. 
   Parse Trees – build and compare parse trees. This allows higher-level similarities to be detected. For instance, tree comparison can normalize conditional statements, and detect equivalent constructs as similar to each other. 
   Program Dependency Graphs (PDGs) – a PDG captures the actual flow of control in a program, and allows much higher-level equivalences to be located, at a greater expense in complexity and calculation time. 
  Metrics – metrics capture 'scores' of code segments according to certain criteria; for instance, "the number of loops and conditionals", or "the number of different variables used". Metrics are simple to calculate and can be compared quickly, but can also lead to false positives: two fragments with the same scores on a set of metrics may do entirely different things. 
  Hybrid approaches – for instance, parse trees +  suffix trees can combine the detection capability of parse trees with the speed afforded by suffix trees, a type of string-matching data structure. 
   The previous classification was developed for  code refactoring, and not for academic plagiarism detection (an important goal of refactoring is to avoid duplicate code, referred to as  code clones in the literature). The above approaches are effective against different levels of similarity; low-level similarity refers to identical text, while high-level similarity can be due to similar specifications. In an academic setting, when all students are expected to code to the same specifications, functionally equivalent code (with high-level similarity) is entirely expected, and only low-level similarity is considered as proof of cheating. 
      Category:Plagiarism detectors 
   Comparison of anti-plagiarism software 
   Locality sensitive hashing 
   Nearest neighbor search 
   Kolmogorov complexity#Compression – used to estimate similarity between token sequences in several systems

<meta content="        Plagiarism detection  is the process of locating instances of  plagiarism within a work or document. The widespread use of computers and the advent of the Internet has made it easier to plagiarize the work of others. Most cases of plagiarism are found in academia, where documents are typically essays or reports. However, plagiarism can be found in virtually any field, including scientific papers, art designs, and source code.   Detection of plagiarism can be either manual or software-assisted. Manual detection requires substantial effort and excellent memory, and is impractical in cases where too many documents must be compared, or original documents are not available for comparison. Software-assisted detection allows vast collections of documents to be compared to each other, making successful detection much more likely.   The practice of plagiarizing by use of sufficient word substitutions to elude detection software is known as  rogeting.   [2]         Software-assisted detection    Computer-assisted plagiarism detection (CaPD) is an  Information retrieval (IR) task supported by specialized IR systems, referred to as plagiarism detection systems (PDS).    In text documents    Systems for text-plagiarism detection implement one of two generic detection approaches, one being external, the other being intrinsic.   [4]  External detection systems compare a suspicious document with a reference collection, which is a set of documents assumed to be genuine.   [6]  Based on a chosen  document model and predefined similarity criteria, the detection task is to retrieve all documents that contain text that is similar to a degree above a chosen threshold to text in the suspicious document.   [8]  Intrinsic PDS solely analyze the text ..." property="og:description"/>

<h5 class="panel-title" id="mobiletitle">
<span><div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="%2FFile%3APDS_Classification.png" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/%2FFile%3APDS_Classification.png/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Enlarge">
</a></div>

Classification of computer-assisted plagiarism detection methods
</div>
</span>
</h5>
</div>

<div class="panel-body infbx-ct" style="padding-top:0px;">
</div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="entry-content">
<div class="mw-body" id="content" role="main"> <div id="siteNotice"> </div>
 <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent"> <div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"> <p> <b> Plagiarism detection </b> is the process of locating instances of <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Plagiarism" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Plagiarism"> plagiarism</a> within a work or document. The widespread use of computers and the advent of the Internet has made it easier to plagiarize the work of others. Most cases of plagiarism are found in academia, where documents are typically essays or reports. However, plagiarism can be found in virtually any field, including scientific papers, art designs, and source code. </p>
 <p> Detection of plagiarism can be either manual or software-assisted. Manual detection requires substantial effort and excellent memory, and is impractical in cases where too many documents must be compared, or original documents are not available for comparison. Software-assisted detection allows vast collections of documents to be compared to each other, making successful detection much more likely. </p>
 <p> The practice of plagiarizing by use of sufficient word substitutions to elude detection software is known as <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Rogeting" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Rogeting/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Rogeting"> rogeting</a>. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grove_1-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="https://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/news/sinister-buttocks-roget-would-blush-at-the-crafty-cheek/2015027.article" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800285/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [2]</a> </sup> </p>
 <p> </p>
 <p> </p>
 <h2 id="software-assisted-detection"> <span class="mw-headline"> Software-assisted detection </span> </h2> <p> Computer-assisted plagiarism detection (CaPD) is an <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Information_retrieval" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Information_retrieval/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Information retrieval"> Information retrieval (IR)</a> task supported by specialized IR systems, referred to as plagiarism detection systems (PDS). </p>
 <h3 id="in-text-documents"> <span class="mw-headline"> In text documents </span> </h3> <p> Systems for text-plagiarism detection implement one of two generic detection approaches, one being external, the other being intrinsic. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stein07_2-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F1328964.1328976" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800288/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [4]</a> </sup> External detection systems compare a suspicious document with a reference collection, which is a set of documents assumed to be genuine. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Potthast09_3-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////www.worldcat.org/issn/1613-0073" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800290/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [6]</a> </sup> Based on a chosen <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Information_retrieval%23Model_types" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Information_retrieval%23Model_types/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Information retrieval"> document model</a> and predefined similarity criteria, the detection task is to retrieve all documents that contain text that is similar to a degree above a chosen threshold to text in the suspicious document. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stein07a_4-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F1277741.1277928" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800297/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [8]</a> </sup> Intrinsic PDS solely analyze the text to be evaluated without performing comparisons to external documents. This approach aims to recognize changes in the unique writing style of an author as an indicator for potential plagiarism. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MeyerZuEissen06_5-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1007%2F11735106_66" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800299/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [10]</a> </sup> PDS are not capable of reliably identifying plagiarism without human judgment. Similarities are computed with the help of predefined document models and might represent false positives. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bao06_6-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://www.plagiarismadvice.org/images/stories/old_site/media/2006papers/JunPengBao.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800300/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [11]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Clough00_7-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://www.ir.shef.ac.uk/cloughie/papers/plagiarism2000.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800301/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [12]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Culwin01_8-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1108%2F03055720010804005" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800304/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [14]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lancaster03_9-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://www.bcu.academia.edu/documents/0009/4554/Lancaster_2003.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800306/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [15]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maurer07_10-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://www.editlib.org/p/26021" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800308/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [16]</a> </sup> </p>
 <h4 id="approaches"> <span class="mw-headline"> Approaches </span> </h4> <p> The figure below represents a classification of all detection approaches currently in use for computer-assisted plagiarism detection. The approaches are characterized by the type of similarity assessment they undertake: global or local. Global similarity assessment approaches use the characteristics taken from larger parts of the text or the document as a whole to compute similarity, while local methods only examine pre-selected text segments as input. </p>
 <div class="center"> </div>
 <h5 id="fingerprinting"> <span class="mw-headline"> Fingerprinting </span> </h5> <p> Fingerprinting is currently the most widely applied approach to plagiarism detection. This method forms representative digests of documents by selecting a set of multiple substrings ( <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="N-gram" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/N-gram/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="N-gram"> n-grams</a>) from them. The sets represent the fingerprints and their elements are called minutiae. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoad03_11-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.18.2680" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800312/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [19]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stein05_12-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://www.uni-weimar.de/medien/webis/publications/papers/stein_2005a.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800313/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [20]</a> </sup> A suspicious document is checked for plagiarism by computing its fingerprint and querying minutiae with a precomputed index of fingerprints for all documents of a reference collection. Minutiae matching with those of other documents indicate shared text segments and suggest potential plagiarism if they exceed a chosen similarity threshold. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brin95_13-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F223784.223855" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800317/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [22]</a> </sup> Computational resources and time are limiting factors to fingerprinting, which is why this method typically only compares a subset of minutiae to speed up the computation and allow for checks in very large collection, such as the Internet. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoad03_11-1"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.18.2680" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800312/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [19]</a> </sup> </p>
 <h5 id="string-matching"> <span class="mw-headline"> String matching </span> </h5> <p> <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="String_matching" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/String_matching/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="String matching"> String matching</a> is a prevalent approach used in computer science. When applied to the problem of plagiarism detection, documents are compared for verbatim text overlaps. Numerous methods have been proposed to tackle this task, of which some have been adapted to external plagiarism detection. Checking a suspicious document in this setting requires the computation and storage of efficiently comparable representations for all documents in the reference collection to compare them pairwise. Generally, suffix document models, such as <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Suffix_tree" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Suffix_tree/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Suffix tree"> suffix trees</a> or suffix vectors, have been used for this task. Nonetheless, substring matching remains computationally expensive, which makes it a non-viable solution for checking large collections of documents. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Monostori00_14-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F336597.336667" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800321/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [24]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Baker93_15-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://cm.bell-labs.com/cm/cs/doc/93/2-bsb-1.ps.gz" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800323/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [25]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Khmelev03_16-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.9.6155" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800325/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [27]</a> </sup> </p>
 <h5 id="bag-of-words"> <span class="mw-headline"> Bag of words </span> </h5> <p> Bag of words analysis represent the adoption of <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Vector_space_model" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Vector_space_model/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Vector space model"> vector space retrieval</a>, a traditional IR concept, to the domain of plagiarism detection. Documents are represented as one or multiple vectors, e.g. for different document parts, which are used for pair wise similarity computations. Similarity computation may then rely on the traditional <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Cosine_similarity" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Cosine_similarity/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Cosine similarity"> cosine similarity measure</a>, or on more sophisticated similarity measures. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Si97_17-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F331697.335176" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800328/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [29]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dreher07_18-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://proceedings.informingscience.org/InSITE2007/IISITv4p601-614Dreh383.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800329/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [30]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Muhr09_19-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://www.uni-weimar.de/medien/webis/research/events/pan-09/pan09-papers-final/zechner09-external-and-intrinsic-plagiarism-detection-using-vsm.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800330/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [31]</a> </sup> </p>
 <h5 id="citation-analysis"> <span class="mw-headline"> Citation analysis </span> </h5> <p> Citation-based plagiarism detection (CbPD) <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gipp14_20-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://www.springer.com/springer+vieweg/it+%26+informatik/k%C3%BCnstliche+intelligenz/book/978-3-658-06393-1" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800331/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [32]</a> </sup> relies on citation analysis, and is the only approach to plagiarism detection that does not rely on the textual similarity. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gipp10_21-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F1810617.1810671" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800333/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [34]</a> </sup> CbPD examines the citation and reference information in texts to identify similar <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Pattern" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Pattern/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Pattern"> patterns</a> in the citation sequences. As such, this approach is suitable for scientific texts, or other academic documents that contain citations. Citation analysis to detect plagiarism is a relatively young concept. It has not been adopted by commercial software, but a first prototype of a citation-based plagiarism detection system exists. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gipp13_22-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F2484028.2484214" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800336/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [36]</a> </sup> Similar order and proximity of citations in the examined documents are the main criteria used to compute citation pattern similarities. Citation patterns represent subsequences non-exclusively containing citations shared by the documents compared. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gipp10_21-1"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F1810617.1810671" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800333/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [34]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gipp11a_23-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F2034691.2034741" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800338/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [38]</a> </sup> Factors, including the absolute number or relative fraction of shared citations in the pattern, as well as the probability that citations co-occur in a document are also considered to quantify the patterns’ degree of similarity. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gipp10_21-2"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F1810617.1810671" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800333/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [34]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gipp11a_23-1"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F2034691.2034741" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800338/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [38]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gipp11_24-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F1998076.1998124" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800344/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [40]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gipp09_25-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////www.worldcat.org/issn/2175-1935" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800349/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [42]</a> </sup> </p>
 <h5 id="stylometry"> <span class="mw-headline"> Stylometry </span> </h5> <p> <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Stylometry" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Stylometry/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Stylometry"> Stylometry</a> subsumes statistical methods for quantifying an author’s unique writing style <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Holmes98_26-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1093%2Fllc%2F13.3.111" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800353/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [43]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Juola08_27-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////www.worldcat.org/issn/1554-0669" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800358/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [46]</a> </sup> and is mainly used for authorship attribution or intrinsic CaPD. By constructing and comparing stylometric models for different text segments, passages that are stylistically different from others, hence potentially plagiarized, can be detected. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MeyerZuEissen06_5-1"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1007%2F11735106_66" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800299/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [10]</a> </sup> </p>
 <h4 id="performance"> <span class="mw-headline"> Performance </span> </h4> <p> Comparative evaluations of plagiarism detection systems <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Potthast09_3-1"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////www.worldcat.org/issn/1613-0073" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800290/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [6]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HTW04_28-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://plagiat.htw-berlin.de/ff-alt/05hilfen/programme.html" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800360/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [47]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HTW08_29-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://plagiat.htw-berlin.de/software/2008/" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800363/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [48]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HTW10_30-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://plagiat.htw-berlin.de/software/2010-2/" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800365/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [49]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Potthast10_31-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://clef2010.org/resources/proceedings/clef2010labs_submission_125.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800367/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [50]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Potthast11_32-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://www.uni-weimar.de/medien/webis/publications/papers/stein_2011t.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800368/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [51]</a> </sup> indicate that their performance depends on the type of plagiarism present (see figure). Except for citation pattern analysis, all detection approaches rely on textual similarity. It is therefore symptomatic that detection accuracy decreases the more plagiarism cases are obfuscated. </p>
 <div class="center"> </div>
 <p> Literal copies, aka copy and paste (c&p) plagiarism, or modestly disguised plagiarism cases can be detected with high accuracy by current external PDS if the source is accessible to the software. Especially substring matching procedures achieve a good performance for c&p plagiarism, since they commonly use lossless document models, such as <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Suffix_tree" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Suffix_tree/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Suffix tree"> suffix trees</a>. The performance of systems using fingerprinting or bag of words analysis in detecting copies depends on the information loss incurred by the document model used. By applying flexible chunking and selection strategies, they are better capable of detecting moderate forms of disguised plagiarism when compared to substring matching procedures. </p>
 <p> Intrinsic plagiarism detection using <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Stylometry" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Stylometry/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Stylometry"> stylometry</a> can overcome the boundaries of textual similarity to some extent by comparing linguistic similarity. Given that the stylistic differences between plagiarized and original segments are significant and can be identified reliably, stylometry can help in identifying disguised and <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Paraphrasing_of_copyrighted_material" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Paraphrasing_of_copyrighted_material/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Paraphrasing of copyrighted material"> paraphrased</a> plagiarism. Stylometric comparisons are likely to fail in cases where segments are strongly paraphrased to the point where they more closely resemble the personal writing style of the plagiarist or if a text was compiled by multiple authors. The results of the International Competitions on Plagiarism Detection held in 2009, 2010 and 2011, <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Potthast09_3-2"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////www.worldcat.org/issn/1613-0073" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800290/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [6]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Potthast10_31-1"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://clef2010.org/resources/proceedings/clef2010labs_submission_125.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800367/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [50]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Potthast11_32-1"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://www.uni-weimar.de/medien/webis/publications/papers/stein_2011t.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800368/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [51]</a> </sup> as well as experiments performed by Stein, <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stein11_33-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////www.worldcat.org/issn/1574-020X" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800374/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [54]</a> </sup> indicate that stylometric analysis seems to work reliably only for document lengths of several thousand or tens of thousands of words, which limits the applicability of the method to CaPD settings. </p>
 <p> An increasing amount of research is performed on methods and systems capable of detecting translated plagiarisms. Currently, cross-language plagiarism detection (CLPD) is not viewed as a mature technology <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Potthast10a_34-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1007%2Fs10579-009-9114-z" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800380/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [56]</a> </sup> and respective systems have not been able to achieve satisfying detection results in practice. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HTW10_30-1"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://plagiat.htw-berlin.de/software/2010-2/" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800365/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [49]</a> </sup> </p>
 <p> Citation-based plagiarism detection using citation pattern analysis is capable of identifying stronger paraphrases and translations with higher success rates when compared to other detection approaches, because it is independent of textual characteristics. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gipp10_21-3"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F1810617.1810671" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800333/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [34]</a> </sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gipp11_24-1"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http:////dx.doi.org/10.1145%2F1998076.1998124" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800344/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [40]</a> </sup> However, since citation-pattern analysis depends on the availability of sufficient citation information, it is limited to academic texts. It remains inferior to text-based approaches in detecting shorter plagiarized passages, which are typical for cases of copy-and-paste or shake-and-paste plagiarism; the latter refers to mixing slightly altered fragments from different sources. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Weber-Wulff08_35-0"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://archive.plagiarismadvice.org/images/stories/old_site/media/2008papers/P21%20Weber-Wulff.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800385/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [57]</a> </sup> </p>
 <h4 id="software"> <span class="mw-headline"> Software </span> </h4> <p> The design of plagiarism detection software for use with text documents is characterized by a number of factors: </p>
 <table class="wikitable"> <tbody> <tr> <th> Factor </th> <th> Description and alternatives </th> </tr> <tr> <td> <b> Scope of search </b> </td> <td> In the public internet, using search engines / Institutional databases / Local, system-specific database. </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <b> Analysis time </b> </td> <td> Delay between the time a document is submitted and the time when results are made available. </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <b> Document capacity / Batch processing </b> </td> <td> Number of documents the system can process per unit of time. </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <b> Check intensity </b> </td> <td> How often and for which types of document fragments (paragraphs, sentences, fixed-length word sequences) does the system query external resources, such as search engines. </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <b> Comparison algorithm type </b> </td> <td> The algorithms that define the way the system uses to compare documents against each other. </td> </tr> <tr> <td> <b> Precision and Recall </b> </td> <td> Number of documents correctly flagged as plagiarized compared to the total number of flagged documents, and to the total number of documents that were actually plagiarized. High precision means that few <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="False_positives" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/False_positives/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="False positives"> false positives</a> were found, and high recall means that few <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="False_negatives" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/False_negatives/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="False negatives"> false negatives</a> were left undetected. </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p> Most large-scale plagiarism detection systems use large, internal databases (in addition to other resources) that grow with each additional document submitted for analysis. However, this feature is considered by some as a <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Turnitin%23Concerns_about_violation_of_student_copyright_in_the_United_States" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Turnitin%23Concerns_about_violation_of_student_copyright_in_the_United_States/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Turnitin"> violation of student copyright</a>. </p>
 <p> The following systems are mostly web-based, and are closed-source, with the exception of CitePlag and CopyTracker. The following list is non-exhaustive (see also <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Comparison_of_anti-plagiarism_software" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_anti-plagiarism_software/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Comparison of anti-plagiarism software"> Comparison of anti-plagiarism software</a>): </p>

 <h3 id="in-source-code"> <span class="mw-headline"> In source code </span> </h3> <p> Plagiarism in computer source code is also frequent, and requires different tools than those used for text comparisons in document. Significant research has been dedicated to academic source-code plagiarism. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://www.ics.heacademy.ac.uk/resources/assessment/plagiarism/research_sourcecode.html" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800401/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [66]</a> </sup> </p>
 <p> A distinctive aspect of source-code plagiarism is that there are no <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Essay_mill" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Essay_mill/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Essay mill"> essay mills</a>, such as can be found in traditional plagiarism. Since most programming assignments expect students to write programs with very specific requirements, it is very difficult to find existing programs that already meet them. Since integrating external code is often harder than writing it from scratch, most plagiarizing students choose to do so from their peers. </p>
 <p> According to Roy and Cordy, <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"> <a class="tooltippableCarat" data-cited_by="wikibot" data-citer_is_verified="0" data-citer_rank="Master Editor" data-username="http://research.cs.queensu.ca/TechReports/Reports/2007-541.pdf" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism_detection/22800402/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> [67]</a> </sup> source-code similarity detection algorithms can be classified as based on either </p>
 <ul> <li> Strings – look for exact textual matches of segments, for instance five-word runs. Fast, but can be confused by renaming identifiers. </li>
 <li> Tokens – as with strings, but using a <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Lexical_analysis" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Lexical_analysis/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Lexical analysis"> lexer</a> to convert the program into <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Token_%28parser%29" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Token_%28parser%29/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Token (parser)"> tokens</a> first. This discards whitespace, comments, and identifier names, making the system more robust to simple text replacements. Most academic plagiarism detection systems work at this level, using different algorithms to measure the similarity between token sequences. </li>
 <li> <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Parse_tree" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Parse_tree/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Parse tree"> Parse Trees</a> – build and compare parse trees. This allows higher-level similarities to be detected. For instance, tree comparison can normalize conditional statements, and detect equivalent constructs as similar to each other. </li>
 <li> <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Call_graph" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Call_graph/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Call graph"> Program Dependency Graphs</a> (PDGs) – a PDG captures the actual flow of control in a program, and allows much higher-level equivalences to be located, at a greater expense in complexity and calculation time. </li>
 <li> Metrics – metrics capture 'scores' of code segments according to certain criteria; for instance, "the number of loops and conditionals", or "the number of different variables used". Metrics are simple to calculate and can be compared quickly, but can also lead to false positives: two fragments with the same scores on a set of metrics may do entirely different things. </li>
 <li> Hybrid approaches – for instance, parse trees + <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Suffix_tree" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Suffix_tree/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Suffix tree"> suffix trees</a> can combine the detection capability of parse trees with the speed afforded by suffix trees, a type of string-matching data structure. </li>
 </ul> <p> The previous classification was developed for <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Code_refactoring" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Code_refactoring/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Code refactoring"> code refactoring</a>, and not for academic plagiarism detection (an important goal of refactoring is to avoid duplicate code, referred to as <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Code_clone" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Code_clone/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Code clone"> code clones</a> in the literature). The above approaches are effective against different levels of similarity; low-level similarity refers to identical text, while high-level similarity can be due to similar specifications. In an academic setting, when all students are expected to code to the same specifications, functionally equivalent code (with high-level similarity) is entirely expected, and only low-level similarity is considered as proof of cheating. </p>
 <h2 id="h2-idh2-idh2h2"> </h2> <ul> <li> <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Category%3APlagiarism_detectors" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Category%3APlagiarism_detectors/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Category:Plagiarism detectors"> Category:Plagiarism detectors</a> </li>
 <li> <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Comparison_of_anti-plagiarism_software" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_anti-plagiarism_software/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Comparison of anti-plagiarism software"> Comparison of anti-plagiarism software</a> </li>
 <li> <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Locality_sensitive_hashing" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Locality_sensitive_hashing/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Locality sensitive hashing"> Locality sensitive hashing</a> </li>
 <li> <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Nearest_neighbor_search" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Nearest_neighbor_search/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Nearest neighbor search"> Nearest neighbor search</a> </li>
 <li> <a class="tooltippable wikilink" data-username="Kolmogorov_complexity%23Compression" href="https://everipedia.org/wiki/Kolmogorov_complexity%23Compression/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Kolmogorov complexity"> Kolmogorov complexity#Compression</a> – used to estimate similarity between token sequences in several systems </li>
 </ul> </div>
 </div>
 </div>

</div>
